article_title: Book Review: 'The First Bohemians' by Vic Gatrell
article_text: Back in his day, George Morland (1763-1804) was a much sought-after British genre painter, but as can be gathered from a late portrait he painted of himself and his skinny assistant in a grimy attic, he wasn't a happy man. Growing up, his father had kept him copying Dutch and Flemish paintings round the clock, and he never shook off the habit of industrious work. Surrounding himself with a menagerie of guinea pigs, rabbits, dogs, pigeons and a donkey serving as models, Morland produced more than 4.000 paintings. But he spent all his earnings on drink—not just the occasional bender but boozing on an epic scale, as a...

article_summary:
But he spent all his earnings on drink—not just the occasional bender but boozing on an epic scale, as a...
Surrounding himself with a menagerie of guinea pigs, rabbits, dogs, pigeons and a donkey serving as models, Morland produced more than 4.000 paintings.
Growing up, his father had kept him copying Dutch and Flemish paintings round the clock, and he never shook off the habit of industrious work.
Back in his day, George Morland (1763-1804) was a much sought-after British genre painter, but as can be gathered from a late portrait he painted of himself and his skinny assistant in a grimy attic, he wasn't a happy man.
